markdownRemark.html:
PXE boot enables booting machines over network by loading installation files from TFTP server. DHCP server needs to be configured to point to TFTP server for PXE boot. When using DNSmasq, this is done by adding dhcp-boot=pxelinux.0,tftp,<tftp_ip_address> within its configuration file (commonly located at /etc/dnsmasq/dnsmasq.conf). More instructions on setting up DNSmasq DHCP/DNS server can be found here.

Install TFTP server

Installing TFTP server can be done by running sudo apt update and sudo apt install -y tftpd-hpa on Ubuntu. However, it is more convenient to run it within Docker container. Create Dockerfile with the following content:

FROM ubuntu:20.04
MAINTAINER republicofdalmatia

RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y tftpd-hpa wget genisoimage git
EXPOSE 69
ENTRYPOINT ["/usr/sbin/in.tftpd"]

Run the following commands to build and run TFTP server within a Docker container (sudo is required for forwarding port 69, while exec enters the container):

docker build -t tftp:latest .
sudo docker run -d --restart=always --name=tftp --hostname=tftp -p 69:69 tftp:latest -v -l -L -s /srv/tftp

Alternativelly, simply pull an already built image with docker pull republicofdalmatia/tftp:latest.

Configure PXE boot

TFTP server needs to hold certain files to serve as PXE boot server. Minimal files include:

  • pxelinux.0 - required for booting over network
  • vesamenu.c32 - defines a menu layout
  • pxelinux.cfg/default - defines menu options for booting
  • autoinstall/user-data - defines autoinstall parameters for Ubuntu 20.04

Setup Ubuntu 20.04 netboot

Download Ubuntu 20.04 iso file from the Ubuntu official website and place it in /srv/tftp/ directory within the tftp container:

docker exec -it tftp /bin/bash
wget -O /srv/tftp/ubuntu.iso https://hr.mirror.kumi.systems/ubuntureleases/20.04.1/ubuntu-20.04.1-live-server-amd64.iso

Extract files vmlinuz and initrd from the .iso file and place them in /srv//tftp/ directory:

isoinfo -i /srv/tftp/ubuntu.iso -x /CASPER/INITRD.\;1 > /srv/tftp/initrd
isoinfo -i /srv/tftp/ubuntu.iso -x /CASPER/VMLINUZ.\;1 > /srv/tftp/vmlinuz

Create autoinstall script for Ubuntu 20.04 and place it inside tftp directory:

Create a file _/var/lib/tftboot/default within a container with the following content:

# D-I config version 2.0
# search path for the c32 support libraries (libcom32, libutil etc.)
PATH menus/
DEFAULT menus/vesamenu.c32
PROMPT 0
TIMEOUT 100
SERIAL 0 9600 #needed for serial output, i.e., servers without graphical card
CONSOLE 1 #put 0 to disable VGA output

LABEL local
        MENU LABEL Boot from the local hard drive
        MENU default
        LOCALBOOT 0

LABEL ubuntu
        MENU LABEL Install Ubuntu 20.04
        kernel vmlinuz
        append autoinstall boot=casper ds=nocloud-net;s=<path/to/autoinstall/script> ip=dhcp url=https://hr.mirror.kumi.systems/ubuntureleases/20.04.1/ubuntu-20.04.1-live-server-amd64.iso initrd=initrd
ramdisk_size=16432 root=/dev/rd/0 rw  --

Add SERIAL 0 9600 at the start of the PXE menu file, where 0 is a serial port ttyS0 and 9600 is a desired baud rate. Additionally, add below CONSOLE 0 to disable VGA output, or CONSOLE 1 to enable VGA output.

For installing Home Assistant on Raspberry Pi please check this cookbook.

Configuring Duck DNS

Duck DNS is used for enabling remote access to the Home Assistant server. It also supports Let's Encrypt for enabling https.

  • Create Duck DNS free account and create a domain. Detailed instructions here.
  • Install Duck DNS add-on and configure it with the following parameters and start it:
lets_encrypt:
  accept_terms: true
  certfile: fullchain.pem
  keyfile: privkey.pem
token: <DUCK_DNS_TOKEN>
domains:
  - <DOMAIN_NAME>.duckdns.org
aliases: []
seconds: 300

For enabling https go to File editor and select configuration.yaml file and add the following configuration. Restart the server afterwards:

http:
  base_url: https://<DOMAIN_NAME>.duckdns.org:<PORT>
  server_port: <PORT>
  ssl_certificate: /ssl/fullchain.pem
  ssl_key: /ssl/privkey.pem
  ip_ban_enabled: true
  login_attempts_threshold: 3

Configure the home router to assign a static IP to the Raspberry Pi and forward the desired external port to Raspberry Pi's <PORT>.

Configure Duck DNS

Duck DNS is a free dynamic DNS service that allows 5 free domains under duckdns.org.

  • Go to Duck DNS official web site and create a free account. You will be assigned a token <DUCK_DNS_TOKEN>.
  • Add a domain by writing your <DOMAIN_NAME> and clicking add domain. Domain will be http://<DOMAIN_NAME>.duckdns.org.
  • Write your router's public IP address and click update ip. You can get it by googling what is my ip.

Auto update IP address

If your router does not have a static public IP, it will probably change at some point. In order to keep Duck DNS up to date, you can write a script that will be running from an always on device inside your home network. Below is an example of systemd service script.

  • Create a file /etc/systemd/user/duckdns.service with the following content:
[Unit]
Description=Updates DuckDNS entry with correct IP address

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=curl -sS "https://www.duckdns.org/update/<DOMAIN_NAME>/<DUCK_DNS_TOKEN>"

Create another file /etc/systemd/user/duckdns.timer with the following content:

[Unit]
Description=Run duckdns.service every 60 seconds

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*-*-* *:*:00
Unit=duckdns.service

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

To enable both unit files and reload systemd daemon, run the following commands:

sudo systemctl enable duckdns.service
sudo systemctl enable duckdns.timer
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl restart duckdns.timer
